chapter.htmlHeader: What is it?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Domestic violence and abuse is defined as any incident or pattern of incidents of controlling, coercive or threatening behaviour, violence, or abuse between people aged 16 years or over who are, or have been, intimate partners or are family members regardless of gender or sexuality [Home Office, 2013].
    • It can encompass, but is not limited to, the following [Home Office, 2013; BMA, 2014; NICE, 2014; DH, 2017]:
      • Psychological abuse — for example intimidation, harassment and stalking, insulting, isolating the person from friends and family, criticizing, treating the person as an inferior, making the person question their own memory, perception, and sanity, and threatening to harm children or take them away.
      • Physical abuse — for example shaking, smacking, punching, kicking, biting, starving, tying up, stabbing, strangulation, suffocation, and throwing things.
      • Sexual abuse — for example forced sex and forced prostitution (both rape), ignoring religious prohibitions about sex, forcing the person to perform sexual acts that they don't enjoy or like, coercing the person into sexual activity, refusal to practice safe sex, sexual insults, passing on sexually transmitted diseases (STIs), and preventing breastfeeding.
      • Emotional abuse — for example swearing, undermining confidence, making racist or sexist remarks, making the person feel unattractive, calling the person names (such as stupid or useless), eroding the person's independence, and threatening to ‘out’ the person's sexual orientation or gender identity to friends, family, or work colleagues.
      • Financial abuse — for example not letting the person work, undermining their efforts to find work or study, refusing to give money,  not letting the person have access to their own money, asking for an explanation of how every penny is spent, making the person beg for money, taking all the money the person earns, gambling, and not paying bills.
    • It also includes:
      • Forced marriage — a marriage in which one or both spouses do not (or, in the case of some adults with learning or physical disabilities, cannot) consent to the marriage but are forced into it using physical, psychological, financial, sexual, or emotional pressure. It is distinct from an arranged marriage, which both partners enter into freely [NICE, 2014].
      • 'Honour'-based violence — a crime or incident committed (or possibly committed) to protect or defend the perceived 'honour' of a family or community [NICE, 2014].
    • The Government’s definition of domestic violence and abuse also includes female genital mutilation (a procedure where the female genital organs are injured or changed for non-medical reasons) [HM Government, 2016; DH, 2017]. However, this is outside the scope of this CKS topic.
    • With the exception of controlling and coercive behaviour in an intimate or family relationship, which was introduced as a criminal offence in December 2015, other acts of domestic violence and abuse fall under generic offence categories in police recorded crime and criminal justice data, such as 'assault with injury' [Office for National Statistics, 2017]:
      • Controlling behaviour is defined as a range of acts designed to make a person subordinate and/or dependent by isolating them from sources of support; exploiting their resources and capacities for personal gain; depriving them of the means needed for independence, resistance, and escape; and regulating their everyday behaviour.
      • Coercive behaviour is defined as a continuing act or a pattern of acts of assault, threats, humiliation, and intimidation or other abuse that is used to harm, punish, or frighten the person into compliance with the perpetrator's demands.
  • Forms of domestic violence and abuse include [NICE, 2014]:
    • Partner abuse among adults, including domestic violence and abuse between parents.
    • Partner abuse among young people (aged 16–18 years).
    • Abuse of parents by children (aged 16 years and older).
    • Abuse of older people. 
  • Domestic violence and abuse occurs across the whole of society, regardless of race, ethnicity, gender, religion, age, class and economic status, or where people live [DH, 2017].
    • It can begin at any time in a relationship and may last a lifetime.
    • Perpetrators can use different forms of abuse at any time during a relationship [RCN, 2017].
    • Unlike other forms of abuse (for example stranger abuse or violence) [RCN, 2017]:
      • Domestic violence and abuse takes place largely in private.
      • The person being abused and the perpetrator are known to each other but are not necessarily partners (for example they may be ex-partners, partners who are not in a sexual relationship, people who are dating, or adult family members).
      • There is often a lack of visual evidence that abuse has taken place.
      • Outsiders may take the view that domestic abuse is less serious.
      • The abuse rarely occurs as an isolated incident; it tends to increase in frequency and severity over time.
      • The perpetrator may have a lot of intimate knowledge about the person being abused, and may hurt them in subtle ways that may not be easily understood by others.
      • Physical injuries are often inflicted on areas of the body that are covered by clothing, for example, breasts and abdomen.
      • The person being abused may not realize they have become a victim because the manipulation is often subtle and can be over a long period of time.
      • It is less likely to be reported to the police.
